title: How to Make Stuffed Baked Marrow

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 395 °F (202 °C) and cut 1 marrow in half lengthwise.
steps.description: Rinse 1 marrow with water and put it on the cutting board. Use a sharp knife to cut it in half lengthwise.

steps.headline: Scoop out the centers and place the halves in a pan.
steps.description: Use a spoon to scoop out the seeds from both marrow halves. Once you've scraped out the seeds, put the marrow halves cut-side up in a large roasting pan. Discard the seeds since they're watery and flavorless.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion for 10 minutes over low heat.
steps.description: Pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil into a saucepan and turn the burner to low. When the oil shimmers, stir in 1 diced onion and cook it until it softens. Stir the onion occasionally to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Stir in the garlic, chorizo, spices, and herbs and cook it for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Add 2 crushed garlic cloves, ⁄4 pound (110 g) of chopped chorizo, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of smoked paprika, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of cayenne pepper, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of dried oregano, and 1/2 teaspoon(1 g) of dried thyme. Stir and cook the mixture for 2 minutes. The chorizo should brown and the garlic will become fragrant once it's cooked.

steps.headline: Add the tomatoes and peppers and cook it for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Open 2 14.5-ounce (411 g) cans of chopped tomatoes and drain them. Add the tomatoes to the saucepan and stir in 3/4 cup (130 g) of sliced roasted red peppers. Simmer the mixture for 10 minutes. Stir the filling mixture occasionally so it doesn't stick to the pan.

steps.headline: Stir in parsley and divide the filling between the 2 marrow halves.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and stir in 1 handful of chopped fresh parsley. Then spoon half of the filling into 1 of the marrow halves in the roasting pan. Scoop the rest of the filling into the other marrow. Spread the filling with the back of a spoon so it's even in the marrow halves.

steps.headline: Cover the pan with aluminum foil and bake the marrow for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Tear off a sheet of aluminum foil and wrap it over the roasting pan. Put the marrow in the preheated oven and cook it for 30 minutes. The marrow will soften and the flavors will develop as the marrow roasts.

steps.headline: Scatter breadcrumbs and manchego over and bake it for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Remove the marrow from the oven and take the foil off the top. Sprinkle 1 2/3 cup (85 g) of fresh breadcrumbs and 1 cup (113 g) of grated manchego over the marrow tops. Put the pan back in the oven and bake the marrow for 10 more minutes. The breadcrumbs should become golden brown.

steps.headline: Serve the Spanish stuffed marrow.
steps.description: Turn off the oven and remove the marrow. Transfer the halves to a platter and serve them immediately. Consider serving the marrow with rice or crusty bread. Refrigerate the leftover marrow in an airtight container for up to 3 to 5 days.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 395 °F (202 °C) and cut the marrow into slices.
steps.description: Get out 1 marrow and use a sharp knife to cut the marrow crosswise into 1.5 in (3.8 cm) slices. You should get about 4 slices from the marrow.

steps.headline: Scoop out the seeds and arrange the rings in a baking dish.
steps.description: Use a spoon to scoop away the seeds from the centers of the slices. Discard the seeds and lay the rings in a baking dish. The rings need to be completely flat so they hold the filling in as they bake.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion, garlic, and red pepper for 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil into a skillet and turn the burner to medium. Once the oil shimmers, stir in 1 diced onion, 2 cloves of minced garlic, and 1 diced red bell pepper. Cook the vegetable mixture until it softens a little. Stir the vegetables occasionally to prevent them from sticking to the pan.

steps.headline: Mix in in the tomato puree, chopped tomatoes, herbs, and beans.
steps.description: Stir 1 tablespoon (16 g) of tomato puree into the skillet and let it cook for a minute. Then add a 14.5-ounce (411 g) can of chopped tomatoes that you've drained, a 14.5 ounce (400 g) can of drained kidney beans, 1 pinch of chili powder, and 1 tablespoon (6 g) of dried mixed herbs or 2 handfuls of fresh herbs. Stir until they're incorporated. For herbs, consider using any combination of thyme, oregano, parsley, basil, or marjoram. You can also add salt and pepper according to your taste.

steps.headline: Simmer the filling for 5 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the burner to medium-low so the filling mixture bubbles gently. Let it cook uncovered for 5 to 10 minutes so the flavors develop and the beans soften a little. Stir the filling mixture frequently and adjust the heat to prevent it from boiling.

steps.headline: Divide the filing between the centers of the marrow rings.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and spoon some of the filling into the middle of each marrow ring in the baking sheet. The filling should come up high on the marrow ring because it will sink down while it bakes.

steps.headline: Cover and bake the marrow rings for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Tear off a sheet of aluminum foil and cover the baking pan. Put the pan in the preheated oven and cook the marrow for 20 minutes. The marrow should soften a little and the filling will be bubbly.

steps.headline: Scatter the cheese over and bake the marrow for another 15 minutes.
steps.description: Remove the pan from the oven and take the foil off. Sprinkle 1 cup (113 g) of grated cheddar cheese evenly over the marrow. Return the pan to the oven and bake them for another 15 minutes. Keep the foil off of the marrow while you finish baking the rings. This will allow the cheese to melt and become golden brown.

steps.headline: Serve the cheese and kidney bean marrow.
steps.description: Turn off the oven and take the baking sheet out. Place the stuffed marrow rings on plates and serve them immediately. Consider serving them with steamed rice or couscous and roasted vegetables. Store the leftover marrow in an airtight container for up to 3 to 5 days.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and remove the marrow seeds.
steps.description: Rinse 1 marrow and set it on a cutting board. Use a sharp knife to carefully slice straight down the marrow lengthwise. Take a spoon and scrape out the seeds from each marrow half. Discard the seeds. The seeds are flavorless and watery, so it's important to remove them before filling the marrow.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion and garlic for 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Pour 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of olive oil into a skillet and turn the burner to medium. When the oil shimmers, stir in 1 chopped onion and 3 cloves of crushed garlic. Stir and cook the mixture until the garlic is fragrant and the onion softens. Stir the mixture frequently so it doesn't stick to the bottom of the pan and burn.

steps.headline: Stir in the ground beef and cook it for 7 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Add 14 ounces (400 g) of ground beef to the skillet and stir to break it up. Cook the ground beef over medium heat until it's completely browned and crumbled. Use the leanest ground beef you can find so it doesn't leave a lot of grease in the skillet.

steps.headline: Stir in the paprika, thyme, oregano, chili flakes, and tomato paste.
steps.description: Stir in 1 teaspoon (2 g) of smoked paprika, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of thyme, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of dried oregano, 1 pinch of chili flakes, and 2 cups (450 g) of tomato paste. Cook the filling for a few minutes so it thickens. Then pour it into a large bowl.

steps.headline: Add breadcrumbs, tomatoes, artichokes, arugula, cheese, and parsley.
steps.description: Put ½ cup (25 g) of fresh breadcrumbs into the bowl with the beef mixture. Stir in ½ cup (25 g) of chopped sundried tomatoes, 1 cup (20 g) of arugula, 2/3 cup (100 g) of crumbled feta, ½ cup (50 g) of grated parmesan cheese, and 1/4 cup (7 g) of the chopped parsley. If you'd like to add artichoke hearts, stir in ½ cup (85 g).

steps.headline: Divide the filling between the marrow halves.
steps.description: Lay the marrow halves cut-side up in a large baking dish. Spoon half of the filling mixture in each marrow half. Then pour 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of olive oil over the top of each marrow.

steps.headline: Pour water in the pan and bake the marrow for 40 minutes.
steps.description: Pour  1 cup (240 ml) of water in the pan and cover the pan with a sheet of aluminum foil. Put the pan in the preheated oven and bake the marrow for 40 minutes. The water will create steam which will help the marrow become tender. If the marrow is still firm after 40 minutes, cook it for another 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Serve the Mediterranean-stuffed marrow.
steps.description: Turn off the oven and remove the pan. Transfer the marrow to plates and sprinkle the remaining 1/4 cup (7 g) of chopped parsley over them as a garnish. Try serving the marrow with couscous, pasta, or a Greek salad. Refrigerate the leftover marrow in an airtight container for up to 3 to 5 days.
